docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the city's fiscal crisis began, the Bloomberg administration is seriously considering a list of potential education cuts that would directly affect classrooms by laying off hundreds of teachers' aides, city officials said yesterday. The possible cuts were submitted to City Hall yesterday by the Department of Education, which, along with every other city agency, was asked to submit lists of proposed budget cuts as a backup plan in case the Bloomberg administration does not win the $600 million worth of concessions it is seeking from the city's labor unions.
docs.abstract: Bloomberg administration is considering list of potential education cuts that would directly affect New York City classrooms by laying off hundreds of teachers' aides and other school employees; Department of Education was asked to cut $180 million or 3.5 percent of its budget (M)
docs.snippet: For the first time since the city's fiscal crisis began, the Bloomberg administration is seriously considering a list of potential education cuts that would directly affect classrooms by laying off hundreds of teachers' aides, city officials said...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten weeks into his term, Senator Bill Frist has adopted a vastly different approach as majority leader, preferring the broad themes and political gestures favored by the White House and conservatives to the pragmatic, back-room tasks favored by his Republican predecessors. While other Republican leaders, including Senators Trent Lott, Bob Dole and Howard H. Baker Jr., were more independent deal makers who prided themselves on keeping the legislative trains running, Dr. Frist is charting a different path as a committed conservative who says he does not intend to compromise his party's principles for momentum.

headline.main: Frist Forsakes Deal Making To Focus on Party Principles

docs.abstract: Sen Bill Frist adopts vastly different approach as majority leader, preferring broad themes and political gestures favored by White House and conservatives to pragmatic, back-room tasks favored by his Republican predecessors; Frist, committed conservative, says he does not intend to compromise his party's principles to keep legislative trains running; many Republican senators speak approvingly of what they describe as more inclusive leadership style than they have seen from Republican leader; some Republican senators are rankled by his style; his interest in large themes has at times resulted in overlooking details, annoying some colleagues; that happened when he reached deal with Democrats on apportioning committees and committee funds that several Republicans consider too generous; he has since hired experts on Senate rules for his staff; while conservatives are pleased with his actions and policies, moderates praise him more for his manner; he is being advised by fellow Tennessean Howard H Baker Jr, former majority leader and now ambassador to Japan who has urged him to meet often with committee chairmen and freshmen; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Ten weeks into his term, Senator Bill Frist has adopted a vastly different approach as majority leader, preferring the broad themes and political gestures favored by the White House and conservatives to the pragmatic, back-room tasks favored by his...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearing the end of a caustic debate over abortion rights, the Senate rejected Democratic efforts today to change or delay a ban on a disputed abortion procedure. It was all but certain that the Republican-controlled Senate would adopt the measure on Thursday.

headline.main: Senate G.O.P. Holds Firm As Vote on Abortion Nears

docs.abstract: Senate rejects Democratic efforts to delay ban on disputed partial-birth abortion procedure; endorses, 52-46, resolution upholding 1973 Roe v. Wade Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion (M)
docs.snippet: Nearing the end of a caustic debate over abortion rights, the Senate rejected Democratic efforts today to change or delay a ban on a disputed abortion procedure.     It was all but certain that the Republican-controlled Senate would adopt the measure...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was 9 o'clock on a Friday night at Mamasan's Bistro in the Mission District and the food was running a little late, but no one seemed to mind. Two dozen diners perched on folding chairs, listening to a hip-hop D.J. spin classic De La Soul in the glow of the Christmas lights dangling overhead. The restaurant's proprietor, a willowy 37-year-old woman who would reveal only her first name, Lynette, was in the kitchen placidly doctoring coconut yams on her crowded four-burner stove. ''This place has become my second home,'' said Carlos Castille, an artist, as he sipped a coconut-mango cocktail. ''There's a comfort to it. It's so mellow. I've brought all my friends.''

headline.main: Restaurants On the Fringe, And Thriving

docs.abstract: Restaurants of dubious legality, where food is cooked in apartments and backyards, abound across United Stats; these underground restaurants range from upscale to gritty, and are born from youthful idealism, ethnic tradition or economic necessity; they lack certification from any government agency and are, strictly speaking, against the law; Mamasan's Bistro in San Francisco cited; photos (M)
docs.snippet: IT was 9 o'clock on a Friday night at Mamasan's Bistro in the Mission District and the food was running a little late, but no one seemed to mind. Two dozen diners perched on folding chairs, listening to a hip-hop D.J. spin classic De La Soul in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David P. Franklin decided within weeks of accepting a job with the drug maker Warner-Lambert that he had become a crucial component in an apparent corporate plan to illegally market an epilepsy drug called Neurontin, he said today. In his first extensive interview since filing a federal lawsuit against the company in 1996, Dr. Franklin said he thought he had little choice but to blow the whistle on what he says was a scheme to ignore federal regulations and market Neurontin for more than a dozen uses it was not approved to treat.

headline.main: Doctor Explains Why He Blew the Whistle

docs.abstract: Dr David P Franklin decided within weeks of accepting job with drug maker Warner-Lambert that he became crucial component in apparent corporate plan to illegally market epilepsy drug called Neurontin; says he thought he had little choice but to blow whistle on what he says was scheme to ignore federal regulations and market drug for more than dozen uses it was not approved to treat, first interview since filing federal lawsuit against Pfizer, which acquired Warner-Lambert, in 1996; Pfizer is negotiating settlement with government prosecutors; issue involves hundreds of millions of dollars that Medicaid and other government programs paid for Neurontin because of what Franklin contends was fraudulent marketing scheme; Pfizer has said actions Franklin claims to have seen would have occurred well before it acquired Warner-Lambert and that it is not aware of any credible evidence that Warner-Lambert employees made false claims about Neurontin; Neurontin accounted for $2.3 billion of Pfizer's sales last year and was one of company's top-selling drugs; Pfizer spokeswoman Mariann Caprino says company policy does not allow sales representatives to make inappropriate claims or encourage use of Pfizer products in treating medical conditions they are not approved for; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. David P. Franklin decided within weeks of accepting a job with the drug maker Warner-Lambert that he had become a crucial component in an apparent corporate plan to illegally market an epilepsy drug called Neurontin, he said today.    In his...

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the House Budget Committee promised today to produce a budget this week that would include all the tax cuts President Bush wanted and still show a balanced budget in seven years because of spending cuts far deeper than Mr. Bush was proposing. In the Senate, opposition to the tax reductions mounted. A bipartisan group of senators who characterize themselves as moderates and who hold the balance of power in the Senate said today that they were close to agreement on a plan that was a fraction of the cuts the president wants.

headline.main: House Budget Chairman Vows Tax Cuts and Balanced Budget

docs.abstract: Rep Jim Nussle, chairman of House Budget Committee, promises to produce budget that will include all tax cuts Pres Bush wants and still show balanced budget in seven years because of spending cuts far deeper than Bush is proposing, sparing only Social Security, unemployment insurance, domestic security and the military; opposition to tax reduction mounts in Senate, where bipartisan group of moderates says it is close to agreement on plan that would provide fraction of cuts that Bush wants (M)
docs.snippet: The chairman of the House Budget Committee promised today to produce a budget this week that would include all the tax cuts President Bush wanted and still show a balanced budget in seven years because of spending cuts far deeper than Mr. Bush was...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans today defeated the first Democratic effort to alter a measure that would ban a disputed abortion procedure, blocking a bid to add expanded birth control insurance coverage and education. Senator Rick Santorum, a Pennsylvania Republican and the chief sponsor of the abortion ban, invoked a procedural objection to a proposal to require private health plans to cover contraceptives, saying its adoption would break budget rules.

headline.main: Senate Blocks an Amendment To Alter an Abortion Measure

docs.abstract: Senate Republicans defeat first Democratic effort to alter measure that would ban partial birth abortion, blocking bid to add expanded birth control insurance coverage and education; vote demonstrates strength of Republican authors of measure, which is expected to pass Congress and be signed into law by Pres Bush (M)
docs.snippet: Senate Republicans today defeated the first Democratic effort to alter a measure that would ban a disputed abortion procedure, blocking a bid to add expanded birth control insurance coverage and education.    Senator Rick Santorum, a Pennsylvania...

docs.lead_paragraph: Few people noticed the lobbyist hovering in the background when Mary Rasar came to the Capitol last week to tell the story of her father's death. With three Republican senators by her side, and a gaggle of reporters before her, Ms. Rasar recounted how her father was injured in a car accident in Las Vegas the day after high liability premiums forced the local trauma center to close. He died in an emergency room -- ''a tragic, tragic story,'' said Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, vowing to press for caps on jury awards in malpractice cases.

headline.main: Lobbyists on Both Sides Duel in the Medical Malpractice Debate

docs.abstract: Hospital lobbyist brings woman to Washington to tell lawmakers how her father died because trauma center at hospital he was bought to after car accident had been shut down because of high liability premiums; appearance is intended to show that there are legitimate victims on both sides of issue, not just malpractice victims brought to Washington by trial lawyers and consumer groups; lobbying reaches fever pitch in both camps as House prepares to take up legislation imposing $250,000 cap on 'pain and suffering' awards in malpractice cases; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Few people noticed the lobbyist hovering in the background when Mary Rasar came to the Capitol last week to tell the story of her father's death.    With three Republican senators by her side, and a gaggle of reporters before her, Ms. Rasar recounted...

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline.main: Fighting the War in Your Head

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students will analyze the experiences of a fictional soldier in a war and create a mental health profile for that individual. They then emulate psychiatrists and propose treatment strategies for their particular soldier's post-traumatic stress disorder.

byline.original: By PRISCILLA CHAN and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: About 5 percent of any group of Medicare patients are made ill by their medicines during treatment outside the hospital over the course of a year, and many of those illnesses can be prevented, a new study has found. Surveys show that almost half of Americans over 65 take five or more different medicines a week.
docs.abstract: Study finds that about 5 percent of any group of Medicare patients are made ill by their medicines during treatment outside hospital over course of year and that many of those illnesses can be prevented; drawing (M)
